details.title: Discounted warranty cost of minimally repaired series systems

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Rutgers Univ., Piscataway, NJ, USA

p: Jun Bai received the B.S. degree in Applied Statistics from Renmin University of China; the M.A. degree in Economics from the American University, Washington DC; and the M.S. degrees in both Statistics and Industrial and Systems Engineering from Rutgers-the State University of New Jersey. Currently he is a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ. His dissertation research is about warranty management and risk analysis for repairable complex systems. He is a student member of INFORMS and IIE.

authors.name: Jun Bai

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Rutgers Univ., Piscataway, NJ, USA

p: Hoang Pham (S'89–M'89–SM'92) received the B.S. degree in Mathematics, B.S. degree in Computer Science, both with high honors, from Northeastern Illinois University, Chicago, the M.S. degree in Statistics from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Industrial Engineering from the State University of New York at Buffalo, in 1982, 1984, 1988, and 1989, respectively. He is an Associate Professor with the Department of Industrial Engineering at Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ. Before joining Rutgers, he was a Senior Engineering Specialist at the Boeing Company, Seattle, and the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, Idaho Falls. His research interests include software reliability, fault-tolerant computing, reliability modeling, maintenance, environmental risk assessment, and optimization.

He is the author of Software Reliability (Springer-Verlag, 2000) and the editor of ten volumes. He has published more than 70 journal articles and 15 book chapters. Among his edited books are Recent Advances in Reliability and Quality Engineering (World Scientific, 2001), Software Reliability and Testing (New York: IEEE Computer Society Press, 1995), and Fault-Tolerant Software Systems: Techniques and Applications (New York: IEEE Computer Society Press, 1992). He is the editor of the Handbook of Reliability Engineering (Springer-Verlag, 2003) and editing the Springer Handbook of Engineering Statistics.

He is Editor-in-Chief of the International Journal of Reliability, Quality and Safety Engineering and Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics. He is Guest Editor of the IIE Trans. on Quality and Reliability and was Guest Editor of the IEEE Trans. on Reliability, Journal of Systems and Software, the International Journal of Modeling and Simulation, and IEEE Communications. He is an editorial board member of the International Journal of Systems Science, Journal of Computer and Software Engineering, IIE Trans. on Quality and Reliability, and the International Journal of Plant Engineering and Management. He has been Conference Chair and Program Chair of over twenty international conferences and workshops and currently the General Chair of the Tenth International Conference on Reliability and Quality in Design will be held in Las Vegas, August 2004. He is a Senior Member of the IEEE, IIE and is listed in Who's Who in the World, Who's Who in America, and Who's Who in Science and Engineering.

authors.name: Hoang Pham

details.abstract: Many factors should be considered in modeling DWC (discounted warranty cost) of repairable systems or products including system structure, components' failure processes, methods of discounting as well as the warranty policy itself. In this paper, we present DWC models for repairable series systems. In particular, a free repair warranty policy and a pro-rata warranty policy are studied. The impact of repair actions on components' failure times is assumed to be minimal, hence NHPPs are used to describe the failure processes. Two types of discounting methods are considered in this paper: a continuous discount function and a discrete discount function. Expressions for both the expected value and variance of DWC are derived. The applications of our findings can be seen in warranty design, warranty reserve determination and risk analysis. Our approach incorporates the information of system structure, the value of time and the impact of repair actions, which are of great importance to warranty cost prediction and evaluation, but have not been sufficiently studied in the literature of warranty analysis.

references.title: Warranty Cost Analysis

context.text: Extensive research on modeling and estimating EWC has been done for various warranty policies; we refer readers to [1]–[4].
In (17), we implicitly assume that the refund function is linear in components' failure times [1], p. 295.
It should be noted that PRW is often used for nonrepairable products such as automobile batteries, television picture tubes, and so forth [1], p. 295.

references.text: W. R. Blischke, D. N. P. Murthy, Warranty Cost Analysis, 1994, Marcel Dekker Inc.

references.title: Product Warranty Handbook

context.text: Extensive research on modeling and estimating EWC has been done for various warranty policies; we refer readers to [1]–[2][4].

A slight modification from the as-good-as-new repair is by assuming a failure time distribution for all the repaired systems, different from the failure time distribution of a new one, for which a delayed renewal process can be employed to model the product failure process [2], p. 139.
There are two widely used methods of time discounting: the continuous discounting and the discrete discounting [2], p. 282, 794.

references.text: W. R. Blischke, D. N. P. Murthy, Product Warranty Handbook, 1996, Marcel Dekker Inc.

references.title: A prediction model of manufacturer warranty reserves

context.text: DWC and warranty reserve related issues have been studied in [6]–[9], from both manufacturers' and consumers' perspectives for single-component products, either repairable or nonrepairable.
For such warranties, it is necessary to consider the system structure as well as the component level warranty service cost [9], p. 543.

However, with the information of the first and second centered moments of DWC per product, it is possible to utilize a Gaussian approximation to solve them for cases such as single lot sales [9], [21].

references.text: M. U. Thomas, "A prediction model of manufacturer warranty reserves", Management Science, vol. 35, no. 12, pp. 1515-1519, 1989.

references.title: Optimal replacement policies for irreparable warranted item

context.text: Ritchken [10] provides an example of a two-component parallel system under a two-dimensional warranty.

links.abstract: This article investigates age replacement policies for irreparable items sold under warranty. Since the costs of replacement depends on terms of warranty, the analysis of age replacement policies is more complex. Optimal age replacement policies that minimize the long run average cost rate are constructed. For warrantied items with increasing failure rates, the optimal policy is to replace functioning items after a finite period of time. A few examples are presented to illustrate the theory.

references.text: P. H. Ritchken, "Optimal replacement policies for irreparable warranted item", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 35, pp. 621-624, 1986.

references.title: Warranty and redundancy design with uncertain quality

context.text: Hussain and Murthy [11] also discuss warranty cost estimation for parallel systems under the setting that uncertain quality of new products may be a concern for the design of warranty programs.

references.text: A. Z. M. O. Hussain, D. N. P. Murthy, "Warranty and redundancy design with uncertain quality", IIE Trans., vol. 30, pp. 1191-1199, 1998.

references.title: Product warranty period: A Markovian approach to estimation and analysis of repair and replacement costs

context.text: A Markovian approach to the analysis of warranty cost for a three-component system can be found in [12].

references.text: K. R. Balachandran, R. Maschmeyer, J. Livingstone, "Product warranty period: A Markovian approach to estimation and analysis of repair and replacement costs", The Accounting Review, vol. 1, pp. 115-124, 1981.

references.title: Warranty Analysis for Complex Systems, Chapter 22 Product Warranty Handbook

context.text: Chukova and Dimtrov [13]derive the expected warranty cost for two-component series systems and parallel systems under a free replacement warranty.

references.title: Cost analysis on renewable full-service warranties for multi-component systems

context.text: Recently, Bai and Pham [14] obtained the first two centered moments of the warranty cost of renewable full-service warranties for complex systems with series-parallel and parallel-series structure.
As shown in [14], various system structure could result in different warranty cost models.

references.text: J. Bai, H. Pham, "Cost analysis on renewable full-service warranties for multi-component systems" in Working Paper, 2002, Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Rutgers University.

references.title: Optimum preventive maintenance policies

context.text: For complex products, repair is often assumed to be minimal (as-good-as-old), which, by the definition in [15], says that the failure rate of a repaired product is the same as that just before the most recent repair. [16] presents a general warranty cost model for single-component repairable products considering as-good-as-new repair, minimal repair and imperfect repair, but the value of time is not addressed.

references.text: R. E. Barlow, L. C. Hunter, "Optimum preventive maintenance policies", Operations Research, vol. 8, pp. 90-100, 1960.

references.title: Cost analysis of warranty policies

context.text: [16] presents a general warranty cost model for single-component repairable products considering as-good-as-new repair, minimal repair and imperfect repair, but the value of time is not addressed.

Due to the instant repair assumption and the structure of series systems, the failure process for each component follows an NHPP on the regular time scale, uniquely determined by \$\lambda _{i}(t)\$[16].

references.text: D. G. Nguyen, D. N. P. Murthy, "Cost analysis of warranty policies", Naval Research Logistics Quarterly, vol. 31, pp. 525-541, 1984.

references.title: Warranty reserves for nonstationary sales processes

context.text: In [17], several warranty reserve models for single-component products are derived for nonstationary sales processes. [18] presents a warranty cost model on minimally repaired single-component systems with time dependent cost.
Discussions on warranty cost variation for single-component or black-box systems can be seen in [17], [19]–[22].
In [17], p. 503, Ja et al. obtain the noncentered first and second moments of the DWC of four types of warranty policies for one-component products.

references.text: S. Ja, V. Kulkarni, A. Mitra, G. Patankar, "Warranty reserves for nonstationary sales processes", Naval Research Logistics, vol. 49, no. 5, pp. 499-513, 2002.

references.title: A renewable minimal-repair warranty policy with time-dependent costs

context.text: [18] presents a warranty cost model on minimally repaired single-component systems with time dependent cost.

links.abstract: Estimating warranty costs during the life cycle of a product is important to the manufacturer, who has to plan for creating a fund for warranty reserves. Replacement or repair costs associated with product-failure within the warranty period are drawn from this fund. This paper considers a policy where warranty is not renewed on product failure within the warranty period but the product is minimally repaired by the manufacturer. This implies that, on repair, the failure rate of the item remains t...

references.text: S. Ja, V. Kulkarni, A. Mitra, G. Partaker, "A renewable minimal-repair warranty policy with time-dependent costs", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 50, pp. 346-352, 2001.

references.title: Cost analysis of two-attribute warranty policies based on the product usage rate

context.text: It is worth noting that for \$q=1\$, the expected DWC is exactly the same as that in Chun and Twang [23], p. 204, but our approach is simpler and more general.

links.abstract: In the so-called two-attribute warranty policy, two types of warranty criteria, such as the age and mileage of an automobile, are employed simultaneously to determine the eligibility of a warranty claim. The authors propose in the paper several decision models that estimate the expected total cost incurred under various types of two-attribute warranty policies. They also perform a sensitivity analysis to study the effects of several model parameters, such as the discount rate, the product usage ...

references.text: Y. H. Chun, K. Tang, "Cost analysis of two-attribute warranty policies based on the product usage rate", IEEE Trans. Engineering Management, vol. 46, pp. 201-209, 1999.

references.title: Optimization Techniques in Statistics

context.text: However, even if no explicit form exists for either \$ {E}[C_{d_{1}}(w)]\$ or \$ {V}[C_{d_{1}}(w)]\$, Newton-Raphson method can still be applied to find \$w^{\ast }\$, for example, by considering polynomial approximations to \$ {E}[C_{d_{1}}(w)]\$ or \$ {V}[C_{d_{1}}(w)]\$ whenever necessary [24], [25].

links.abstract: A fully scalable and SPICE compatible wideband model of on-chip interconnects valid up to 110 GHz is presented in this paper. The series branches of the proposed multisegment model consist of an RL ladder network to capture the skin and proximity effects, as well as the substrate skin effect. Their values are obtained from a technique based on a modified effective loop inductance approach and complex image method. A CG network is used in the shunt branches of the model, which accounts for capaci...

references.text: J. S. Rustagi, Optimization Techniques in Statistics, 1994, Academic Press.

references.title: Imperfect maintenance

context.text: First is to consider imperfect repair [26], [27] instead of minimal repair.

links.abstract: This paper studies a multi-objective maintenance optimization embedded within the imperfect preventive maintenance (PM) for one single-unit system subject to the dependent competing risks of degradation wear and random shocks. We consider two kinds of random shocks in the system: 1) fatal shocks that will cause the system to fail immediately, and 2) nonfatal shocks that will increase the system degradation level by a certain cumulative shock amount. Also, an improvement factor in the form of qua...

references.text: H. Pham, H. Wang, "Imperfect maintenance", European Journal of Operational Research, vol. 94, pp. 425-438, 1996.
